What do you know about the statistical problem-solving process?

Statistics involves asking a question, collecting data, analyzing the data, and interpreting the data to answer the question.

Sometimes it is not possible, or you are not able, to collect data from a whole population. Representative samples of the population can be used to predict the answers for the whole population.

For samples to be representative, they must be large enough and random enough to mirror the population. Sample size can influence the reliability of sample statistics and resulting conclusions and predictions. Different sampling plans can influence the reliability of sample statistics and resulting conclusions and predictions.

Samples vary and summary statistics of samples, even same-sized samples, taken from the same population also vary.

We can use measures of center (mean, median, or mode) and spread (range, IQR, or MAD) to summarize a sample.

We can use statistics from representative samples to draw conclusions about populations.
